meanings.def: in or into a position covering, touching or forming part of a surface
examples: a picture on a wall
There's a mark on your skirt.
the diagram on page 5
Put it down on the table.
He had been hit on the head.
She climbed on to the bed.

meanings.def: supported by somebody/something
examples: She was standing on one foot.
Try lying on your back.
Hang your coat on that hook.

meanings.def: used to show a means of transport
examples: He was on the plane from New York.
to travel on the bus/tube/coach
I came on my bike.
a woman on horseback

meanings.def: by means of something; using something
examples: She played a tune on her guitar.
The information is available on the internet.
We spoke on the phone.
What's on TV?
The programme's on Channel 4.

meanings.def: used to show a day or date
examples: He came on Sunday.
We meet on Tuesdays.
on May the first/the first of May
on the evening of May the first
on one occasion
on your birthday

meanings.def: used to describe an activity or a state
examples: to be on business/holiday/vacation
The book is currently on loan.

meanings.def: used to show direction
examples: on the left/right
He turned his back on us.

meanings.def: at or near a place
examples: a town on the coast
a house on the Thames
We lived on an estate.

meanings.def: used to show the basis or reason for something
examples: a story based on fact
On their advice I applied for the job.

meanings.def: immediately after something
examples: On arriving home I discovered they had gone.
Please report to reception on arrival.
There was a letter waiting for him on his return.

meanings.def: about something/somebody
examples: a book on South Africa
She tested us on irregular verbs.

meanings.def: used to show that somebody belongs to a group or an organization
examples: to be on the committee/staff/jury/panel
Whose side are you on (= which of two or more different views do you support)?

meanings.def: eating or drinking something; using a drug or a medicine regularly
examples: He lived on a diet of junk food.
The doctor put me on antibiotics.

meanings.def: paid for by something
examples: to live on a pension/a student grant
to be on a low wage
You can't feed a family on £50 a week.
Drinks are on me (= I am paying).

meanings.def: used when giving a phone number
examples: You can get me on 020 7946 0887.
She's on extension 2401.

meanings.def: used with some nouns or adjectives to say who or what is affected by something
examples: a ban on smoking
He's hard on his kids.
Go easy on the mayo! (= do not take/give me too much)

meanings.def: being carried by somebody; in the possession of somebody
examples: Have you got any money on you?

meanings.def: compared with somebody/something
examples: Sales are up on last year.

meanings.def: on somebody’s body; being worn
examples: Put your coat on.
I didn't have my glasses on.
What did she have on (= what was she wearing)?

meanings.def: covering, touching or forming part of something
examples: Make sure the lid is on.

meanings.def: in or into a vehicle
examples: The bus stopped and four people got on.
They hurried on to the plane.

meanings.def: connected or operating; being used
examples: The lights were all on.
The TV is always on in their house.
We were without electricity for three hours but it's on again now.

meanings.def: used to show that somebody/something moves or is sent forward
examples: She stopped for a moment, then walked on.
Keep straight on for the beach.
From then on he never trusted her again.
Please send the letter on to my new address.

meanings.def: used to show that something continues
examples: He worked on without a break.
If you like a good story, read on.

meanings.def: happening
examples: There was a war on at the time.
What's on at the movies?
The band are on (= performing) in ten minutes.

meanings.def: planned to take place in the future
examples: The game is still on (= it has not been cancelled).
I don't think we've got anything on this weekend.
I'm sorry we can't come—we've got a lot on.

meanings.def: on duty; working
examples: I'm on now till 8 tomorrow morning.

meanings.def: to talk about something; to mean something
examples: I didn't know what he was on about. It didn't make sense.

meanings.def: to talk in a boring or complaining way about something
examples: Stop keeping on about it!

meanings.def: to keep asking or telling somebody something so that they become annoyed or tired
examples: He was on at me again to lend him money.

meanings.def: to want to do something
examples: Is anyone on for a drink after work?

meanings.def: used to say that something is not acceptable
from time to time; now and again
examples: It rained on and off all day.

meanings.def: without stopping; continuously
examples: She went on and on about her trip.

meanings.def: used when you are very surprised at somebody’s behaviour and are suggesting that they are acting in a similar way to somebody using drugs
used when you are accepting a bet

idioms.def: to talk about something; to mean something
examples: I didn't know what he was on about. It didn't make sense.

idioms.def: to talk in a boring or complaining way about something
examples: Stop keeping on about it!

idioms.idiom: be/go/keep on at somebody (to do something)
idioms.def: to keep asking or telling somebody something so that they become annoyed or tired
examples: He was on at me again to lend him money.
Is anyone on for a drink after work?

idioms.def: used to say that something is not acceptable
from time to time; now and again
examples: It rained on and off all day.
She went on and on about her trip.

idioms.def: used when you are very surprised at somebody’s behaviour and are suggesting that they are acting in a similar way to somebody using drugs
used when you are accepting a bet
